By TED ROHRLICH

The Student Council, Monday night,
agreed that the Academic Council had made a
sufficiently "positive response" to student
demands for 1969 implementation of the
proposed 4-1-4 system of calendar reform to
warrant cancellation of plans calling for a
general student strike.
The Council also voted to set up a
mechanism "that will allow as many faculty
members as possible to be contacted personally
to insure their support of the proposed
calendar." According to SC President Russ
Passarella, "The most important thing that
students can do at this point is to get out and
enthusiastically encourage the faculty to support
the 4-1-4 reforms."
A school wide referendum is slated for
March 10 and 11 "to manifest the widespread

support for the proposals" of the Ad Hoc
Committee on the Academic Calendar, which
were submitted to President Lincoln Gordon on
February 25.

the recommendations of its Strike Committee,
composed of Russ Passarella, Manuel Rodriguez,
Chuck Steinberg, and Martin Hickey, which met
with the Academic Council in a lengthy session
last week.
At that time, faced with the possibility of
a student strike, the Academic Council agreed to
call an extraordinary meeting of the faculty
General Assembly for March 14, at 4:00 p.m. in

no return for implementation in 1969, is the end

proposed student strike came as an
acknowledgement of the "good will and spirit"
on the part of Dr..Gordon and the Academic
Council.

The General Faculty Assembly acts only

Council. However, it is unlikely that the Council
would defy an Assembly mandate on calendar
reform, either pro or con.
The main SC deliberations, however,

wording of the student referendum. Dave Clark
suggested that a proposition be included calling
for a strike if the Academic Council does not

1969. .

strike at this time might be interpreted by the
faculty as undue pressure and result in a General
Assembly backlash.

the university: "continuing or maintaining

After a period of long delay,

building program by breaking

week.
The first diggings for the new

parking lot area which is located south

Students,Congressmen Fight To Save Youth Fare
By PHIL HEAGNEY
Campus Editor

Since the Civil Aeronautics Board
announced its recommendation in late January
that student youth fares offered by airlines
should be abolished, it has faced a steadily
growing number of opponents who are seeking
to prevent final approval of the CAB ruling.
The original recommendation was handed
down by the CAB on January 22nd. At that
time, CAB Examiner Arthur Present attacked
the fares as being "unjustly discriminatory"
against passengers who are over 21.
Both the National Student Marketing Corporation
and the National Student Association reacted to the
ruling by announcing that they would fight for a
reversal. A group called Campus Americans for
Democratic Action has joined in the protest and all three
groups will represent student interests by filing briefs in
favor of youth fares at the next CAB hearing on March
12th.
Congressional Response
Members of Congress have also reacted against the
proposed ban. At least 16 Representatives, led by Rep.

Arnold Olsen (D. Montana)have introduced a resolution
in the House supporting the continuation of all children,
youth and military fares on domestic airlines. The
resolution claims that such fares are not inconsistent
with the intent and purposes of the Federal Aviation Act
of 1958 as is claimed by some members of CAB.
Representative James Scheuer (D. New York) has
offered an amendment to the 1958 Aviation Act that
would explicitly give the CAB the right to grant Youth
Fares. Senator Percy of Illinois has introduced a similar
measure in the Senate.
No Benefits
Representative Olsen contended that "No one
would benefit from an elimination of these fares. As a
matter of fact, it would very likely lead to a general
increase in fares because two of the three fare categories
involved apply only to seats which would otherwise go
vacant."
A group of students on the Hopkins campus has
also been involved in fighting the CAB ruling. They
collected signatures for a petition from Hopkins,
Towson State, and Baltimore Junior College. The
petitions included more than 1300 signatures and they
were presented to the CAB this past Wednesday along
with petitions from 4000 students from the Washington,
D.C. area.

One student in the Hopkins group said that a
student committee will continue to push for a reversal of
the CAB's ruling. The committee hopes to mount a
campaign to interest more congressmen in the problem
and it has urged all Hopkins students to write to their
congressmen or at least send them a special Western
Union telegram. Since the final decision on youth fares
has not been made yet, the committee thinks that there
is still some chance for incluencing the final outcome.
The NSA is willing to go beyond the CAB to keep
youth fares alive. The group has retained the services of
a Washington law firm, Koteen and Burt, who are
experts in the field of air fares. The group claims that it
will take the issue to court if the final CAB ruling is
unfavorable. The NSA will present oral arguments at the
upcoming CAB hearings.
The NSA position claims that youth fares should
not be abolished because they create "an extraordinary
opportunity to broaden educational horizons" by
bringing air travel within the reach of students for the
first time. Moreover, the NSA claims that the banning of
youth fares is being pushed by a special lobby group
representing the major bus companies of the country.

Electrical Engineering Chairman Believes
Reduction in Military Research 'Remote"
"The Electrical Engineering
Department is continuing in its
policy of performing 'classified'
and 'military applications'
research for the military," said
Ferdinand Hamburger, the
department head, who see "the
possibilities for further reduction
as remote."
In the last year for which figures
are available, August 1967 to September
1968, the Electrical Engineering
Department members published 9 trade
reports, 2 of which were classified, 10
internal memos, 3 of which were
classified, and 4 quarterly reports,
portions of all of which were classified.
Hamburger pointed out the
significant decrease in the amount of
classified research being produced by his
department, indicating that as little as
ten years ago nearly 50% of the papers
from Electrical Engineering were
classified documents. As for the
break-down of the actual time normally
devoted by the researcher to military
research, Hamburger felt that it had not
"changed significantly."
80% Of His Time
The typical researcher working
under a military contract devotes 80%
of HS' time to applied but not
necessarily classified research. At least
half of this time is spent on research
which is definitely not classified. The
other half is directed along more closely
militarily-related topics. Of the

remaining 20%, 5% of the researchers
time is free to work in any area he
desires; 15% is devoted to esoteric
research pursuits which would normally
not be investigated were it not for the
military support.
hamburger indicates that "If we
had our druthers, we would prefer not
to do any classified research at all." He
felt, however, that "for the amount of
classified 'research we do, it is a small
price to pay for what they pay for basic
research." "It also might be considered
a basic duty of the university to support
our nation," he added.
Many of the research reports
which are classified are also published in
slightly bowlderized form for the
general consumption. What is deleted
from the classified report is a "military
rider," usually in the form of an
introduction, which explains to the
military the applications of the research
to their needs. "It is necessary," said
Hamburger, "that we demonstrate to
the military that our basic research can
be of use to them; it may happen that
the military might not even understand
the research that was done." He tells the
, story of one researcher who published
;the same paper twice, once with a
military applications introduction, as a
classified document, and once as an
unclassified document with a normal
introduction. The only difference
between the two papers was the
introduction.
Hamburger, thought, that the
,
Military applications riders were

necessary, since "the research is

the researcher to pursue
basical-orientated research and still have
it supported by the military. Hamburger
felt that it did not restrict the workers
in any way, and did often allow them

AWARE Hits Landlords Today's Campus Disorders:
orNeglecting InnerCity Looking Where They're At
Eugene Groves, a graduate student
in the Department of Social Relations,
and several members of AWARE have
indicted 20 of Baltimore's leading slum
landlords for major negligence of their
property in inner city areas.
The indictment appeared in a
preliminary report which the group
released this week. It is part of a major
survey which the group is making on the
activities of slum landlords in Baltimore.
The group is relying on records from the
Department of Housing and Community
Development, as the basis for their
study.
Their findings will be used to
show the urgent need for more strict
enforcement of the Maryland Rent
Defence Bill when the Bill is reviewed in
the State Senate. The Rent Defens:e Bill
is designed, in part, to protect the
tenent from eviction or higher rents
after he lodges a complaint about the
services of his landlord.
Complaints Listed
Baltimore housing inspectors and
other housing agency officials gave

AWARE a list of 20 of the worst
slumlords. Jim Archibald, Kathy Lewis,
Dick Janis, and Joan and Eugene Groves
found that complaints against some of!
them had gone untended since 1965.
Herbert Kaufman had the most
outstanding notices with 123, followed
by Louis Shapiro with 83. Other leading
offenders were the Needle's, the Kalis',
and the Klotzman's.
A 30-day or a 60-day notice is
issued to a landlord after a complaint
has been made by one of his tenants and
has been found to be valid by a Housing
Department inspector. Often landlords
will attempt to obtain a 60-day notice,
usually only given to less pressing cases,
in order to get time to avoid the
complaint by evicting the tenant.
AWARE is using the Eisenhower library
computer to correlate the number of
outstanding complaints against a
landlord with both the number of
60-day notices obtained and the number
of complaining tenants evicted.
AWARE's findings have been
written up in the Baltimore SUN and
have drawn two lawsuit threats from
exposed landlords.

the ways of Hopkins; it had a purpose.

In high school, remember, they rounded up all the
kids in the Driver's Ed. program, stuck you in the school

flicks. Remember the Last Prom? Remember Signal 30?
Remember the one where the two cats are roaring down
the highway in this beat up Buick and one says, "I think
the carburator's leaking" and you see this huge Mack
truck barreling down the highway in the opposite
direction; "Gee," says the driver, "I should of gotten

while the two cats become a firmly embedded part of
the national highway system? You dug that? Go see
Weekend.
Why? Because Jean-Luc Godard's movie is the
epitome of all that you should have seen in those driver's
ed. flicks, all that you did see if you dreamed about
them or had the marvelous good fortune to see them
stoned. On one level, the connection is obvious:
Godard's extensive use of the car wreck as background,
foreground, plot divider and symbol, thus shooting the
wad of the cinematic bloody pavement motif. Cars are
everywhere, most of them wrecked. Cars are the world,
most of it twisted, flaming bloody. I'm impressed.
There is more, though, and the "more" goes past
the wrecks to answer that nagging ache from high
school—hey, what am I getting into when I start this
driving thing? The car, as J. Edgar Hoover deemed fit to
say, is "a motel room on wheels". But while you get
your piece of ass, you're also getting a piece of tentacle
from a compulsively grabbing culture of materialism, a
culture which is willing to take 250,000 casulties a year

to keep automotivated—a culture which calls your ass
less important than GM profits, a situation whicli
Godard endeavors to remind the viewer, may not be
entirely to his benefit.

proof of Godard's staleness, any good- history of the
twentieth century confirming this staleness beyond

daring French director has done nothing less than
present a concise history of the feel, the feel, the feel of
this, our troubled and tumultuous century. Permit me to
object. Permit me to puke.
Look, what Godard has done has been to take this
idea of bloody mechanization (which has roots in not
more than half the literature of the twentieth century)
and add his own limited potpourri of cinematic fetishes
and social ills. So fans, sit back, bear in mind the twisted
wrecks of automobiles, let the sickly devices waft to you
like pigeon bombs in a strong wind:
!!!!SEE: a long, long monologue by faded image

!!!!SEE: Boredom, but it's all right because you're

For a good twenty minutes (it seems longer) a man
walks round and round a barnyard to the twangs of a

!!!!SEE: Politics, yes Shriver, politics, the kind of

one's pockets picked. Monologues from Mao, third
world leaders, the wave of the future people. Okay, they

masochism, as the Fugs put it, Nuh-thing. Filming the

Zzzzzzzzzz.
Thus, reactionary critique of a "daring cinamatic

not willing to masturbate enthusiasm for an "art film",

non-existant highpoint of the boredom scene.

Our American Heritage,

Did You Celebrate This Occasion?
By ED MENDELSOHN
A centennial has passed, and members of the
Johns Hopkins community should be cognizant of the
fact. March 4, 1969 was the centennial of the
inauguration of Ulysses Simpson Grant as the eighteenth
President of the United States. Mr. Grant's most famous
postwar statement is "Let us have peace." He did not
issue this laudable sentiment on March 4. It came at the
end of his letter accepting the 1868 Republican
Presidential nomination. This innocuous sentiment is
famous because it became a campaign issue. It was
asserted that Mr. Grant's opponent in the Presidential
canvass, Governor Horatio Seymour of New York, in
effect favored violence, since he had made a speech
during the 1863 draft riots and referred to his auditors
as "My friends." He had not been addressing rioters at
the time, but this impression was created by
Republicans. Particularly culpable was cartoonist
Thomas Nast, who is best known for more laudable
enterprises.
On March 4, Mr. Grant's banalities could not be
contrasted to distortions of the banalities of Governor
Seymour, but could only fall on their MD weight. I
presume this is why I detected no interest in
commemorating the inaugural. Nevertheless, the balance
of this piece will proceed on the assumption that the
General expressed a few thoughts which are worth
remembering.
Mr. Grant began by expressing confidence in his
own ability. "The responsibilities of the position I feel,
by I accept them without fear." It is interesting that Mr.
Grant was not a dynamic President, but that here he
indicated a desire to establish a strong position. He
quickly said that he would make known his opinions to
Congress. This opened possible vistas. If Mr. Grant spoke
to congress, he would be the first to do so since John
Adams. As it happened, the next President to speak to
congress was Woodrow Wilson.
Veto
He also made clear that, upon disagreeing with
Congressional legislation, he would exercise his
Constitutional privilege of the veto. The growth of the
executive power has been gradual, and in the post-Civil
War period it was not to be striking, but this statement
represents a culmination in one area. Twenty-eight years
before President William Henry Harrison, in a speech
assaulting by implication those powers assumed by
President Jackson, had declared that the veto should be
restricted to those occasions when the President
considers the legislation in question unconstitutional.
Mr. Grant gave a • brief but clear outline of
economic policy. He stated that all debts would be paid,

and that he favored the use of specie. There was a
shortage of it, but he made reference to the "strong box
of precious metals" in "the sterile mountains of the
West" which he implied had been set aside by
Providence to solve this difficulty. It was not then a
Republican doctrine that gold was a more desirable
form of specie than silver. Even as late as 1881,
President Garfield supported active use of both metals in
financial transactions.
President Grant did express the desire for unity
following the late war. His only reference to the Negro
was a wish that the voting question would be solved by
ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment, which shortly
followed. He did not in this speech advocate any changes
in the Reconstruction legislation as then constituted. It
may be added that, had Texas and Virginia been able to
vote in the 1868 election, Mr. Grant's narrow popular
vote victory would have been imperilled.

Mr. Grant also expressed some interest in Indian
affairs. He said that he would favor a course leading to
"civilization and citizenship" for the aborigines. No
important legislation on this point was actually passed in
the Grant administration, and several Indian wars were
yet to come.
It is evident from his reference to the veto power,
and his taking a strong stand on economic matters,
Negro voting and Indian citizenship, that President
Grant desired to be a reasonably active and strong
executive. He was extremely vague on foreign policy,
simply stating that the U.S. cultivated good relations
with other powers, and would respond in kind to
antagonism on the part of others.
For no President has the Inaugural Address been a
moment of weakness. In the Inaugural the President
commands the stage and formulates the dominant ideas.
After this statement of a theory of executive power, the
nation watched to see if Mr. Grant could translate
theory into practice.

The Students for a Democratic Society has
recently embarked upon action to relieve the
oppressed conditions of the workers at Johns
Hopkins. The adoption of this cause is a
tremendous improvement over the course that
SDS took last semester when all attention was
devoted to issues removed from the immediate
environment of University life. This apparent
shift to active concern for what is happening
close to home is a welcome relief. They have
fallen short, however, of touching issues that
promise to arise the concern and attention of

workingman. SDS, the leading national radical

existing student organizations, to deal with these
matters.

improve the conditions of the laborer in American
society. Apparently the Hopkins chapter of the

the action. Is there a deep concern for the betterment of
conditions and salary of the workers, not to mention the
demands for an all expenses .paid education for the

eager to deal with issues that may bring this about more
than issues that \ire likely to change the institution. This
policy is warped, a course of action that would bring
about changes that may better the lives of the students
at Hopkins would prove far more profitable in the long
run although it may be less dramatic.

Show how the real world is indeed

bold,

Primarily in a nonlinear aural tradition,

Open to the public. While most of these

"He" was substituted
,

while of greatest interest to the scholar,
are of relatively little importance in the
proper interpretation of the text and
thus I will say no more about them.
However any student interested in
pursuing this topic further should
consult the magnificent thirty volume
'study of The Texts and Techniques in
the Study of Folk Literature: A
Beginner's Guide to Ethno-Philology in
the Middle Atlantic Region of the

This poem is a p.suedolimerick, for
a true limerick has anapestic lines
rhymed aabba whereas our texts
consists of iambs rhymed abccb—though
there is internal rhyme in the first line.
Ostensibly it is a comic lyric meant to
achieve effect by playing on advances in
the methods of prophylaxis. However a
close reading will reveal that this little
poem deals with great and weighty
matter.
Boudoir of Truth
The key which will unlock the
door which bars our entrance into
Truth's chamber, the thread which will
guide us through the labyrinth of
multiple meanings, is to be found in the
word "rubbers," suggesting as it does
the everyday world of utility in its
meaning gumband or overshoes on the
one hand, and on the other, the
meaning obviously intended suggesting
the world of sensual pleasure in its

reference to those prophylactic devices
invented to prevent the spread of the
diseases of Venus. Notice that this
duality is implicit in the sock used in
days of old, for sock is normally worn
on the foot, just as the overshoe can be
(topologically) transformed into a
prophylactic device in the service of
Venus. Thus one of the devices
operating in this poem is the
transformation of the merely utilitarian
into the hedonistic. This transformation
is achieved by the elasticity which is
implicit in the notion of rubbers as
gumbands; it is the elasticity of the
human mind which sees that a sock can
do service as a prophylactic device. Thus
the transformation of the utilitarian
into the hedonistic is effected by the
human imagination seeing a new use in
an ordinary everyday thing—a sock. It is
the call of the hedonistic element in
man which prompts the imagination to
inventiveness.
New Dimensions
Yet, there is another dimension to
"rubbers" which we must explore.
Rubber only became practical with the
invention of vulcanization. This clear
allusion to Vulcan, the workman of the
gods, mirrors the allusion to Minerva,
the weaver of the gods and therefore
responsible for socks. Further, Vulcan
was wedded to Venus and cuckolded by
Mars, the god of war and the most
vainglorious of the gods. This reference
to Mars clearly mirrors the opening
mention of knighthood. Thus the folk
genius has introduced a clear conflict
between utility and hedonism through
mythical allusion.

Clearly, this folk poem has as its

imagination which prompted our
knightly forefathers to the use of the
sock as a prophylactic device, it was an

overshoes into condoms and it was an,
act of imagination which gave birth to
the process of vulcanization which
effected an improvement upon older
methods of prophylaxis. But this
magnificent outpouring of imaginative
activity was prompted not out of the
hard working utilitarianism of Vulcan
but out of the vainglorious hedonism of
Mars, for the poem explicitly says that
it was babies which were prevented and
not disease. The moral is clear: the
imagination in service to the
vainglorious hedonism of Mars can only
lead to strife and the thwarting of the
Divinely ordained mode of human
creativity, the union of man and woman
in the creative act to the greater glory of
God and the continuation of the
species.
Thus it is clear that the vulgar
world is indeed relevant to the sublime
world of the university and that the
•vulgar poets have in fact seen that most
sublime of truths that Man must live in
the light of the Lord and according to
his laws and render unto Him his due. If
• this is only now coming to light it is
because too few scholars have been
willing to place the blubber of folk
poetry into the try works of the truth
seeking mind and labor diligently to
render forth the pure fat of Divine
truth.

Jose Strike Ends
(CPS)—The American Federation of Teachers
chapter at San Jose College voted Feb. 19 to accept an
administration offer to settle the grievances in a strike
that began Jan. 8.
The 42-45 vote to end the strike before voting on
the settlement brought the resignations of President
Eldred E. Rutherford and two other chapter officers.
Rutherford called the proposed settlement "a piece of
toilet paper."
The strike was generally regarded as ineffective
with less than half the union's 190 members joining the
picket lines. The settlement included rehiring 28 strikers
who were threatened with loss of their jobs under a
California law that says any professor who misses five
class days is considered to have resigned. Other
provisions included creation of a faculty committee to
hear professor's grievances and having an outside
fact-finder study the teachers' demand for reduction of
the 12-hour teaching load.
The strike was originally called in sympathy with
the one terminated this week at San Francisco State
College.

Dissent Threatened
The New Democratic Coalition, a reform alliance
within the Democratic Party, urged political leaders to
speak out against "a growing movement in this country
for the repression of dissent, particularly on campus."
The Coalition's steering committee, after a
two-day meeting in Washington, warned that the
repression "is seen in threats to scholarships of those
who oppose certain university policies, reduced
appropriations for state universities, the use .of military
and draft law to quiet dissent and the growing use of
police violence against those who protest."
The organization also called on the FBI and the
Justice Department to "cease all investigations
concerned with the political beliefs and affiliations of
dissidents." The Coalition, composed of former workers
in the presidential campaigns of Sen. Eugene McCarthy
and the late Sen. Robert F. Kennedy, now has affiliated
groups in 28 states, according to its leaders.

The move to lower the Maryland voting age below
the traditional level of 21 appeared to be dead for the
legislative session as the House of Delegates reversed its
earlier tentative approval of a constitutional amendment
extending the franchise to 20-year-olds and 19-year-olds.
The lower house of the Maryland General
Assembly Monday night rejected the voting bill, 61-73 in
favor, 13 votes short of the three-fifths majority of 86
needed to place a constitutional amendment before the
voters.
The measure had received tentative approval by a
tally of 93-36 last Thursday on a second reading of the
bill. Opponents of the bill have argued that teen-agers
and 20-year-olds generally are not mature and
responsible enough to vote. Others said they feared
inclusion of the measure on the ballot might endanger
more important constitutional amendments expected to
be put before the voters.

them how to vote as well as we teach them how to fight,
there might be some validity."

institutions and suggested it could be accomplished by
the fall of 1970.
The Harvard Corporation, their governing body,
met this morning to consider the request, made nine

full merger with Harvard. The letter to Radcliffe's
president said, "In principle, we welcome the prospect

initiating the question. We shall be happy to join with
you in a discussion of when and how such a merger
might be effected."
Harvard and Radcliffe students have been going to
the same classes together over the last 25 years.
However, the two schools have retained their separate
corporate identities and dormitories. Points to be
discussed by the two universities include funding,
personnel employment and ratio of men to women.

Students,Congressmen Fight To Save Youth Fare
By PHIL HEAGNEY
Campus Editor

Since the Civil Aeronautics Board
announced its recommendation in late January
that student youth fares offered by airlines
should be abolished, it has faced a steadily
growing number of opponents who are seeking
to prevent final approval of the CAB ruling.
The original recommendation was handed
down by the CAB on January 22nd. At that
time, CAB Examiner Arthur Present attacked
the fares as being "unjustly discriminatory"
against passengers who are over 21.
Both the National Student Marketing Corporation
and the National Student Association reacted to the
ruling by announcing that they would fight for a
reversal. A group called Campus Americans for
Democratic Action has joined in the protest and all three
groups will represent student interests by filing briefs in
favor of youth fares at the next CAB hearing on March
12th.
Congressional Response
Members of Congress have also reacted against the
proposed ban. At least 16 Representatives, led by Rep.

Arnold Olsen (D. Montana)have introduced a resolution
in the House supporting the continuation of all children,
youth and military fares on domestic airlines. The
resolution claims that such fares are not inconsistent
with the intent and purposes of the Federal Aviation Act
of 1958 as is claimed by some members of CAB.
Representative James Scheuer (D. New York) has
offered an amendment to the 1958 Aviation Act that
would explicitly give the CAB the right to grant Youth
Fares. Senator Percy of Illinois has introduced a similar
measure in the Senate.
No Benefits
Representative Olsen contended that "No one
would benefit from an elimination of these fares. As a
matter of fact, it would very likely lead to a general
increase in fares because two of the three fare categories
involved apply only to seats which would otherwise go
vacant."
A group of students on the Hopkins campus has
also been involved in fighting the CAB ruling. They
collected signatures for a petition from Hopkins,
Towson State, and Baltimore Junior College. The
petitions included more than 1300 signatures and they
were presented to the CAB this past Wednesday along
with petitions from 4000 students from the Washington,
D.C. area.

student committee will continue to push for a reversal of
the CAB's ruling. The committee hopes to mount a
campaign to interest more congressmen in the problem
and it has urged all Hopkins students to write to their
congressmen or at least send them a special Western
Union telegram. Since the final decision on youth fares
has not been made yet, the committee thinks that there
is still some chance for incluencing the final outcome.
The NSA is willing to go beyond the CAB to keep
youth fares alive. The group has retained the services of
a Washington law firm, Koteen and Burt, who are
experts in the field of air fares. The group claims that it
will take the issue to court if the final CAB ruling is
unfavorable. The NSA will present oral arguments at the
upcoming CAB hearings.
The NSA position claims that youth fares should
not be abolished because they create "an extraordinary
opportunity to broaden educational horizons" by
bringing air travel within the reach of students for the
first time. Moreover, the NSA claims that the banning of
youth fares is being pushed by a special lobby group

In high school, remember, they rounded up all the

from a compulsively grabbing culture of materialism, a

object. Permit me to puke.

Our American Heritage,

Did You Celebrate This Occasion?
By ED MENDELSOHN
A centennial has passed, and members of the
Johns Hopkins community should be cognizant of the
fact. March 4, 1969 was the centennial of the
inauguration of Ulysses Simpson Grant as the eighteenth
President of the United States. Mr. Grant's most famous
postwar statement is "Let us have peace." He did not
issue this laudable sentiment on March 4. It came at the
end of his letter accepting the 1868 Republican
Presidential nomination. This innocuous sentiment is
famous because it became a campaign issue. It was
asserted that Mr. Grant's opponent in the Presidential
canvass, Governor Horatio Seymour of New York, in
effect favored violence, since he had made a speech
during the 1863 draft riots and referred to his auditors
as "My friends." He had not been addressing rioters at
the time, but this impression was created by
Republicans. Particularly culpable was cartoonist
Thomas Nast, who is best known for more laudable
enterprises.
On March 4, Mr. Grant's banalities could not be
contrasted to distortions of the banalities of Governor
Seymour, but could only fall on their MD weight. I
presume this is why I detected no interest in
commemorating the inaugural. Nevertheless, the balance
of this piece will proceed on the assumption that the
General expressed a few thoughts which are worth
remembering.
Mr. Grant began by expressing confidence in his
own ability. "The responsibilities of the position I feel,
by I accept them without fear." It is interesting that Mr.
Grant was not a dynamic President, but that here he
indicated a desire to establish a strong position. He
quickly said that he would make known his opinions to
Congress. This opened possible vistas. If Mr. Grant spoke
to congress, he would be the first to do so since John
Adams. As it happened, the next President to speak to
congress was Woodrow Wilson.
Veto
He also made clear that, upon disagreeing with
Congressional legislation, he would exercise his
Constitutional privilege of the veto. The growth of the
executive power has been gradual, and in the post-Civil
War period it was not to be striking, but this statement
represents a culmination in one area. Twenty-eight years
before President William Henry Harrison, in a speech
assaulting by implication those powers assumed by
President Jackson, had declared that the veto should be
restricted to those occasions when the President
considers the legislation in question unconstitutional.
Mr. Grant gave a • brief but clear outline of
economic policy. He stated that all debts would be paid,

and that he favored the use of specie. There was a
shortage of it, but he made reference to the "strong box
of precious metals" in "the sterile mountains of the
West" which he implied had been set aside by
Providence to solve this difficulty. It was not then a
Republican doctrine that gold was a more desirable
form of specie than silver. Even as late as 1881,
President Garfield supported active use of both metals in
financial transactions.
President Grant did express the desire for unity
following the late war. His only reference to the Negro
was a wish that the voting question would be solved by
ratification of the Fifteenth Amendment, which shortly
followed. He did not in this speech advocate any changes
in the Reconstruction legislation as then constituted. It
may be added that, had Texas and Virginia been able to
vote in the 1868 election, Mr. Grant's narrow popular
vote victory would have been imperilled.

Mr. Grant also expressed some interest in Indian
affairs. He said that he would favor a course leading to
"civilization and citizenship" for the aborigines. No
important legislation on this point was actually passed in
the Grant administration, and several Indian wars were
yet to come.
It is evident from his reference to the veto power,
and his taking a strong stand on economic matters,
Negro voting and Indian citizenship, that President
Grant desired to be a reasonably active and strong
executive. He was extremely vague on foreign policy,
simply stating that the U.S. cultivated good relations
with other powers, and would respond in kind to
antagonism on the part of others.
For no President has the Inaugural Address been a
moment of weakness. In the Inaugural the President
commands the stage and formulates the dominant ideas.
After this statement of a theory of executive power, the
nation watched to see if Mr. Grant could translate
theory into practice.

Show how the real world is indeed

nunds can fix their earnest gaze

well known piece of popular verse.

bold,

Around their cock

the matter of textual authentitity.

Primarily in a nonlinear aural tradition,
a few texts are available to the intrepid

bowels and emptying of the bladder
Open to the public. While most of these

Thus babies were prevented" and in

in still another
"He" was substituted
,

their." However, these differences,

while of greatest interest to the scholar,
are of relatively little importance in the
proper interpretation of the text and
thus I will say no more about them.
However any student interested in
pursuing this topic further should
consult the magnificent thirty volume
'study of The Texts and Techniques in
the Study of Folk Literature: A
Beginner's Guide to Ethno-Philology in
the Middle Atlantic Region of the
United States from 1237 A.D. Until
1957 A.D. with Special Emphasis on the

This poem is a p.suedolimerick, for
a true limerick has anapestic lines
rhymed aabba whereas our texts
consists of iambs rhymed abccb—though
there is internal rhyme in the first line.
Ostensibly it is a comic lyric meant to
achieve effect by playing on advances in
the methods of prophylaxis. However a
close reading will reveal that this little
poem deals with great and weighty
matter.
Boudoir of Truth
The key which will unlock the
door which bars our entrance into
Truth's chamber, the thread which will
guide us through the labyrinth of
multiple meanings, is to be found in the
word "rubbers," suggesting as it does
the everyday world of utility in its
meaning gumband or overshoes on the
one hand, and on the other, the
meaning obviously intended suggesting
the world of sensual pleasure in its

reference to those prophylactic devices
invented to prevent the spread of the
diseases of Venus. Notice that this
duality is implicit in the sock used in
days of old, for sock is normally worn
on the foot, just as the overshoe can be
(topologically) transformed into a
prophylactic device in the service of
Venus. Thus one of the devices
operating in this poem is the
transformation of the merely utilitarian
into the hedonistic. This transformation
is achieved by the elasticity which is
implicit in the notion of rubbers as
gumbands; it is the elasticity of the
human mind which sees that a sock can
do service as a prophylactic device. Thus
the transformation of the utilitarian
into the hedonistic is effected by the
human imagination seeing a new use in
an ordinary everyday thing—a sock. It is
the call of the hedonistic element in
man which prompts the imagination to
inventiveness.
New Dimensions
Yet, there is another dimension to
"rubbers" which we must explore.
Rubber only became practical with the
invention of vulcanization. This clear
allusion to Vulcan, the workman of the
gods, mirrors the allusion to Minerva,
the weaver of the gods and therefore
responsible for socks. Further, Vulcan
was wedded to Venus and cuckolded by
Mars, the god of war and the most
vainglorious of the gods. This reference
to Mars clearly mirrors the opening
mention of knighthood. Thus the folk
genius has introduced a clear conflict

mythical allusion.

imagination which prompted our
knightly forefathers to the use of the

overshoes into condoms and it was an,
act of imagination which gave birth to
the process of vulcanization which
effected an improvement upon older
methods of prophylaxis. But this
magnificent outpouring of imaginative
activity was prompted not out of the
hard working utilitarianism of Vulcan
but out of the vainglorious hedonism of
Mars, for the poem explicitly says that
it was babies which were prevented and
not disease. The moral is clear: the
imagination in service to the
vainglorious hedonism of Mars can only
lead to strife and the thwarting of the
Divinely ordained mode of human
creativity, the union of man and woman
in the creative act to the greater glory of
God and the continuation of the
species.
Thus it is clear that the vulgar
world is indeed relevant to the sublime
world of the university and that the
•vulgar poets have in fact seen that most
sublime of truths that Man must live in
the light of the Lord and according to
his laws and render unto Him his due. If
• this is only now coming to light it is
because too few scholars have been
willing to place the blubber of folk
poetry into the try works of the truth
seeking mind and labor diligently to
render forth the pure fat of Divine
truth.
